Simple equations

1. Solving equations

Solving equations with fractions

Solve the following equation.

x−x2=4x−x2=4

Your answer should be exact (no rounding).

Answer: x=x=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Use multiplication to remove the denominator from the equation. Then solve for the variable.

STEP: Simplify the equation by removing the denominator
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We need to find the value of xx which solves the given equation. Since there is a fraction in the equation, it is a good idea to start our solution by multiplying by the LCD of the fraction. We do this to cancel the denominator, which simplifies the equation.

In this case, we just multiply by 22 (there is only the one denominator to cancel). But remember that we must multiply all of the terms in the equation.

x−x2(2)x−(2)x22x−x=4=4(2)=8x−x2=4(2)x−(2)x2=4(2)2x−x=8
STEP: Combine the terms on the left and solve
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now that there are no fractions in the equation. So we can easily combine the terms on the left side of the equation and solve for xx.

2x−xx=8=82x−x=8x=8

The solution to the equation is x=8x=8.

Two-step linear equations

Solve for cc:

4+6c=−54+6c=−5
INSTRUCTION: Give you answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer: c=c=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

You must try to get cc on its own with a coefficient of 11. First you must subtract 44 from both sides of the equation. Then you must divide both sides of the equation by 66.

STEP: Solve for cc
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get cc on its own. To do this we must do the opposite of what has been done to cc.

The 44 has been added to the cc, so we must subtract 44 from both sides of the equation.

4+6c4+6c−46c=−5=−5−4=−94+6c=−54+6c−4=−5−46c=−9

Now we can focus on getting the coefficient of cc to be 11. To get cc on its own with a coefficient of 11, we must do the opposite of what has been done to cc. We must divide both sides of the equation by 66.

6c6c6cc=−9=−96=−96=−326c=−96c6=−96c=−96c=−32
NOTE: You might have tried to solve this equation by first dividing both sides by the coefficient of cc (which is 66 in this case). This would give you the correct answer, as long as you remembered to divide 44 by 66. But, this method can create fractions that are difficult to work with. (It is also easy to forget to divide 44 by 66!) It is best to first deal with the number, and only divide by the coefficient of cc as the very last step.

Linear equations: variables on both sides

Solve for yy: 13+7y=y13+7y=y

INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer: y=y=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]
Use inverse operations to get all of the yy's on one side of the equation, and the numbers on the other.
STEP: Solve for yy
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Whenever we are solving equations, we should start by checking if we can simplify each side. For this question, both sides are already simplified, so we can move on. The next step is to get all of the yy 's on one side of the equation, and the numbers on the other side.

We can see that 7y7y is on the same side as the number. To eliminate it, we need to subtract 7y7y from both sides of the equation.

13+7y∴13+7y−7y∴13=y=y−7y=−6y13+7y=y∴13+7y−7y=y−7y∴13=−6y

Now that we have the yy--terms on one side and the numbers on the other, we need to divide both sides by the coefficient of yy.

∴13−6∴13−6∴−136y=−6y−6=y=y=−136∴13−6=−6y−6∴13−6=y∴−136=yy=−136

Additive inverse

Solve for pp:

7=p+27=p+2
Answer: p=p=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get pp on its own.

STEP: <no title>
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get the variable on its own.

To get pp on its own we must do the opposite of what has been done to pp. The 22 has been added to pp, so we must subtract 22 from both sides of the equation.

7∴7−2∴5∴p=p+2=p+2−2=p=57=p+2∴7−2=p+2−2∴5=p∴p=5
NOTE: "Doing the same thing to both sides" to get pp on its own is also called "applying the inverse operation."

Multi-step linear equations

Solve for rr:

−6+2(2+r)=−3(3r−1)−7r−6+2(2+r)=−3(3r−1)−7r
INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer:

r=r=

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Simplify each side of the equation by using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

STEP: Simplify each side of the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

The first thing that we must do when solving linear equations is check if we can simplify each side. In this question we can use the distributive law to multiply out the brackets, then collect like terms.

−6+2(2+r)∴−6+4+2r∴−2+2r=−3(3r−1)−7r=−9r+3−7r=−16r+3−6+2(2+r)=−3(3r−1)−7r∴−6+4+2r=−9r+3−7r∴−2+2r=−16r+3
STEP: Get the variables on the one side of the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

Now that we have simplified each side of the equation, it looks much more manageable. The next step is to get the rr's on the left hand side of the equation. We want to eliminate the −16r−16r from the right hand side, so we need to add 16r16r to both sides of the equation.

−2+2r∴−2+2r+16r∴−2+18r=−16r+3=−16r+3+16r=3−2+2r=−16r+3∴−2+2r+16r=−16r+3+16r∴−2+18r=3
STEP: Use inverse operations to isolate rr
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]
−2+18r∴−2+18r+2∴18r∴18r18∴r=3=3+2=5=518=518−2+18r=3∴−2+18r+2=3+2∴18r=5∴18r18=518∴r=518
NOTE:

There are many different ways that you can solve linear equations. But, these three steps will always get you to the right answer:

  1. Simplify each side of the equation (remember order of operations!).
  2. Get the variables on the left hand side.
  3. Use inverse operations to isolate the variable.

Equations with fractions

Solve for aa:

−25a−1=−2−25a−1=−2
INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer: a=a=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

First add 11 from both sides of the equation. Then multiply both sides of the equation by the reciprocal of −25−25.

STEP: Solve for aa using inverse operations
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get aa on its own. The 11 has been subtracted from the aa-term. So, we must add 11 to both sides of the equation.

−25a−1∴−25a−1+1∴−25a=−2=−2+1=−1−25a−1=−2∴−25a−1+1=−2+1∴−25a=−1

Now we need to get the coefficient of aa to be 11. So we need to think about what number to multiply −25−25 by, to get it to 11. To get rid of the denominator, we need to multiply by 55. In the next step we will divide by −2−2 to get rid of the numerator.

−25a∴5×−25a∴−2a∴−2a−2∴a∴a=−1=5×(−1)=−5=−5−2=−5−2=52−25a=−1∴5×−25a=5×(−1)∴−2a=−5∴−2a−2=−5−2∴a=−5−2∴a=52
NOTE: You could have also multiplied both sides by the reciprocal, −52−52.

Mystery value

Find the mystery value MM.

INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as an integer or as a fraction.
Answer: The correct value of MM is: .
numeric
STEP: Write down an equation based on the balanced scale
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

An equation in mathematics can be compared to a balance scale: everything on the left side of the balance must be equal to everything on the right side of the balance. In this question, we need to find the value of MM which will balance the two sides of the scale in the diagram.

Based on this idea, we can write the following equation from the diagram above:

Left sideM÷36=Right side=1Left side=Right sideM÷36=1
STEP: Solve the equation
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

Now we can solve the equation. To do this we use inverses to isolate the variable.

M36M36×36M=1=1×36What you do on the one sideyou do on the other side.=36M36=1M36×36=1×36you do on the other side.What you do on the one sideM=36

Since 36÷3636÷36 is the same as 11, M=36M=36 is the number which balances the equation. Going back to the original diagram, it now looks like this:

The correct answer is M=36M=36.

Linear equations: variables on both sides

Solve for pp:

−2p−4=4p−5−2p−4=4p−5
INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as a simplified fraction.
Answer:

p=p=

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Subtract 4p4p from both sides of the equation to get all the pp's on the left hand side.

STEP: Get the pp's on the left hand side
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

We need to use the idea of doing the same thing to both sides to get all of the pp's onto the left hand side of the equation. Then the equation will look like the equations that we can already solve.

We want to get rid of 4p4p on the right hand side so that we only have pp's on the left hand side of the equation. To do so, we must subtract 4p4p from both sides.

−2p−4∴−2p−4−4p∴−6p−4=4p−5=4p−5−4p=−5−2p−4=4p−5∴−2p−4−4p=4p−5−4p∴−6p−4=−5
STEP: Solve the equation using inverse operations
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

The equation should now look familiar. We can solve it by doing the same thing to both sides, to get pp on its own.

−6p−4∴−6p−4+4∴−6p∴−6p−6∴p=−5=−5+4=−1=−1−6=16−6p−4=−5∴−6p−4+4=−5+4∴−6p=−1∴−6p−6=−1−6∴p=16

Solving equations with brackets

Solve for bb:

−4(b+13)=34−4(b+13)=34
Answer: b=b=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The first thing to do is multiply the −4−4 into the binomial (b+13)(b+13).

STEP: Distribute the −4−4 into the binomial
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

−4(b+13)−4b−52=34=34−4(b+13)=34−4b−52=34
STEP: Isolate the variable to solve the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can use inverses to solve the equation. Inverses help isolate the variable, which is exactly what we want to do. Notice that if we move the −4b−4b term to the right, it will become positive!

−4b−52−52−52−34−86−432=34=4b+34=4b=4b=b−4b−52=34−52=4b+34−52−34=4b−86=4b−432=b

The correct answer is b=−432b=−432.

Setup the equation

The balance scale below is balanced. That means it has the same weight on both sides.
In the answer box below type the whole equation represented by this balanced scale.

Answer: The equation is: .
equation
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

From the picture you need to identify what goes on each side of the equation. Then write the equation with an equal sign between the two sides.

STEP: Solution
[−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

This scale is in balance, so the right side is equal to the left side. So something = something else.

STEP: Balance scale
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

An equation in mathematics can be compared to a balance scale. The fulcrum in a balance scale is at the exact center of the bar. In mathematics this can be compared to the equal sign. Everything on the left side of the equal sign must be equal to everything on the right side of the equation just like a balance scale.

Your equation should look like this: 96t=1996t=19.

Multiplicative inverse

Solve for aa:

−5=−5a−5=−5a
Answer: a=a=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Do the same thing to both sides of the equation so that the coefficient of aa is 11.

STEP: Solve for aa
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We want the coefficient of aa to be 11. We have −5a−5a, which means that aa is being multiplied by −5−5. To get aa on its own with a coefficient of 11, we must do the opposite of what has been done to aa; we must divide by −5−5. Whenever we solve equations, we must do the same thing to both sides to make sure that the value of the equation remains the same. So, we must divide both sides of the equation by −5−5.

−5−5−5−5−51a=−5a=−5a−5=a=a=1−5=−5a−5−5=−5a−5−5−5=a1=aa=1
NOTE: 1a1a means the same thing as aa (because when you multiply any number by 11, you get the same number). We usually write aa instead of 1a1a because it is easier, and Mathematicians like things to be as easy as possible.

Solving linear equations

Solve for xx:

4x=2x+24x=2x+2
Answer: x=x=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by combining the two xx-terms. To do this, you must subtract either 4x4x or 2x2x from both sides of the equation.

STEP: Use inverses to solve the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to collect all the xx-terms together on one side of the equation. Then all the terms without a variable (the constants terms) will be on the other side. Then work towards removing the xx-coefficient.

4x4x−(2x)2x2x×(12)x=2x+2=2x−(2x)+2=2=2×(12)=14x=2x+24x−(2x)=2x−(2x)+22x=22x×(12)=2×(12)x=1

The correct solution is x=1x=1.

Multiplicative inverse

Solve for cc:

1=c71=c7
Answer: c=c=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Multiply both sides of the equation by 77 to get rid of the fraction.

STEP: Solve for cc
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We want to get cc on its own. To get cc on its own, we must do the opposite of what has been done to cc. In this question cc has been divided by 77, so we must multiply by 77. Whenever we solve equations, we must do the same thing to both sides to make sure that the value of the equation remains the same. So, we must multiply both sides of the equation by 77.

11×77c=c7=c7×7=c=71=c71×7=c7×77=cc=7
NOTE: "Getting cc on its own" is called isolating cc.

The distribution law and equations

Solve for aa:

−8=−5(−3a+3)−8=−5(−3a+3)
INSTRUCTION: Give your answer as a simplified fraction. Decimal answers will not be marked as correct.
Answer: a=a=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

The first thing you should do is distribute the −5−5 into the binomial (−3a+3)(−3a+3). After that, continue to solve the equation.

STEP: Simplify the right hand side of the equation
[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

The first thing that we do when solving equations is simplify each side of the equation. We can use the distributive law to simplify the right hand side of this equation. The left hand side is already simplified, so we will leave it as is for now.

−8−8−8=−5(−3a+3)=−5×(−3a)−5×(3)=15a−15−8=−5(−3a+3)−8=−5×(−3a)−5×(3)−8=15a−15
STEP: Use inverses to solve for aa
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now we can solve the equation using inverse operations to isolate aa.

−8−8+157715715a=15a−15=15a−15+15=15a=15a15=a=715−8=15a−15−8+15=15a−15+157=15a715=15a15715=aa=715
NOTE: You could have also solved this equation by first dividing both sides by −5−5.

Exercises

Solving equations with fractions

Solve the following equation.

4b3−b2=64b3−b2=6

Your answer should be exact (no rounding).

Answer: b=b=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

Use multiplication to remove the denominators from the equation. Then solve for the variable.

STEP: Simplify the equation by removing the denominators
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 3 points left]

We need to find the value of bb which solves the given equation. Since there are fractions in the equation, it is a good idea to start our solution by multiplying by the LCD of the fractions. We do this to cancel the denominators, which simplifies the equation.

Multiply each term in the equation by the lowest common denominator (LCD) of the two fractions. For these fractions, the LCD is 66.

4b3−b2(6)4b3−(6)b28b−3b=6=6(6)=364b3−b2=6(6)4b3−(6)b2=6(6)8b−3b=36
STEP: Combine the terms on the left and solve
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

Now that there are no fractions in the equation. So we can easily combine the terms on the left side of the equation and solve for bb.

8b−3b5bb=36=36=3658b−3b=365b=36b=365

The solution to the equation is b=365b=365.

Solving equations with fractions

Two-step linear equations

Solve for mm:

−3+4m=−7−3+4m=−7
Answer: m=m=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

You must try to get mm on its own with a coefficient of 11. First you must add 33 to both sides of the equation. Then you must divide both sides of the equation by 44.

STEP: Solve for mm
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get mm on its own. To do this we must do the opposite of what has been done to mm.

The 33 has been subtracted from the mm, so we must add 33 to both sides of the equation.

−3+4m−3+4m+34m=−7=−7+3=−4−3+4m=−7−3+4m+3=−7+34m=−4

Now we can focus on getting the coefficient of mm to be 11. To get mm on its own with a coefficient of 11, we must do the opposite of what has been done to mm. We must divide both sides of the equation by 44.

4m4m4m=−4=−44=−14m=−44m4=−44m=−1
NOTE: You might have tried to solve this equation by first dividing both sides by the coefficient of mm (which is 44 in this case). This would give you the correct answer, as long as you remembered to divide −3−3 by 44. But, this method can create fractions that are difficult to work with. (It is also easy to forget to divide −3−3 by 44!) It is best to first deal with the number, and only divide by the coefficient of mm as the very last step.

Two-step linear equations

Solve for mm:

−3=1−m−3=1−m
Answer: m=m=
fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 3 / 3 points left]

You must try to get mm on its own with a coefficient of 11. First you must subtract 11 from both sides of the equation. Then you must divide both sides of the equation by −1−1.

STEP: Solve for mm
[−3 points ⇒ 0 / 3 points left]

To solve a linear equation, we do the same thing to both sides of the equation to get mm on its own. To do this we must do the opposite of what has been done to mm.

The 11 has been added to the mm, so we must subtract 11 from both sides of the equation.

−3−3−1−4=1−m=1−m−1=−m−3=1−m−3−1=1−m−1−4=−m

Multi-step linear equations

Solve for xx:

2x+3(−4x−2)=−2−(2+x)2x+3(−4x−2)=−2−(2+x)

Answer:

x=x=

fraction
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

Simplify each side of the equation by using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

STEP: Simplify each side of the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

The first thing that we must do when solving linear equations is check if we can simplify each side. In this question we can use the distributive law to multiply out the brackets, then collect like terms.

2x+3(−4x−2)∴2x−12x−6∴−10x−6=−2−(2+x)=−2−2−x=−4−x2x+3(−4x−2)=−2−(2+x)∴2x−12x−6=−2−2−x∴−10x−6=−4−x
STEP: Get the variables on the one side of the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]

Now that we have simplified each side of the equation, it looks much more manageable. The next step is to get the xx's on the left hand side of the equation. We want to eliminate the −x−x from the right hand side, so we need to add xx to both sides of the equation.

−10x−6∴−10x−6+x∴−9x−6=−4−x=−4−x+x=−4−10x−6=−4−x∴−10x−6+x=−4−x+x∴−9x−6=−4
STEP: Use inverse operations to isolate xx
[−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]
−9x−6∴−9x−6+6∴−9x∴−9x−9∴x=−4=−4+6=2=2−9=−29−9x−6=−4∴−9x−6+6=−4+6∴−9x=2∴−9x−9=2−9∴x=−29
NOTE:

There are many different ways that you can solve linear equations. But, these three steps will always get you to the right answer:

  1. Simplify each side of the equation (remember order of operations!).
  2. Get the variables on the left hand side.
  3. Use inverse operations to isolate the variable.

STEP: Solve for pp
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We want the coefficient of pp to be 11. We have 2p2p, which means that pp is being multiplied by 22. To get pp on its own with a coefficient of 11, we must do the opposite of what has been done to pp; we must divide by 22. Whenever we solve equations, we must do the same thing to both sides to make sure that the value of the equation remains the same. So, we must divide both sides of the equation by 22.

−10−102−5p=2p=2p2=p=−5−10=2p−102=2p2−5=pp=−5
NOTE: 1p1p means the same thing as pp (because when you multiply any number by 11, you get the same number). We usually write pp instead of 1p1p because it is easier, and Mathematicians like things to be as easy as possible.

Solving linear equations

Solve for bb:

6b=5b+86b=5b+8
Answer: b=b=
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

Start by combining the two bb-terms. To do this, you must subtract either 6b6b or 5b5b from both sides of the equation.

STEP: Use inverses to solve the equation
[−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

We need to collect all the bb-terms together on one side of the equation. Then all the terms without a variable (the constants terms) will be on the other side.

6b6b−(5b)1bb=5b+8=5b−(5b)+8=8=86b=5b+86b−(5b)=5b−(5b)+81b=8b=8

The correct solution is b=8b=8.

fraction

[−1 point ⇒ 2 / 3 points left]

−(z+5)−1×(z)−1×(5)−z−5=2=2=2−(z+5)=2−1×(z)−1×(5)=2−z−5=2

2. Practical applications

Out of data

Mcebisi uses the internet on his cellphone for homework assigments. This uses up data, which can be used in-bundle or out-of-bundle. Mcebisi's cellphone network charges different rates for in-bundle and out-of-bundle data usage.

Last week, he used 44 MB44 MB of data in-bundle, and 6 MB6 MB of data out-of-bundle. Out-of-bundle data costs R1,40R1,40 more than twice the cost of in-bundle data, per MBMB.

Let the cost of in-bundle data (per MBMB) be yy.

  1. Write an expression for the cost of out-of-bundle data (per MBMB), in terms of yy.

    Answer: Cost of out-of-bundle data == rand (per MBMB)
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    Out-of-bundle data costs R1,40R1,40 more than twice the cost of in-bundle data, per MBMB. You must add R1,40R1,40 to the product of R2R2 and yy.

    STEP: Write an expression for the cost of out-of-bundle data
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    Out-of-bundle data costs R1,40R1,40 more than twice the cost of in-bundle data, per MBMB. We must add R1,40R1,40 to the product of R2R2 and yy.

    out-of-bundle data cost (per MB)=2×(cost of in-bundle data)+1,4=2×(y)+1,4=2y+1,4out-of-bundle data cost (per MB)=2×(cost of in-bundle data)+1,4=2×(y)+1,4=2y+1,4
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Mcebisi paid R103,60R103,60 for his data last week. (He got into big trouble with his mom.) Use an equation to calculate the cost of both in-bundle and out-of-bundle data, per MBMB.

    Answer: Cost of in-bundle data == RR per MBMB
    Cost of out-of-bundle data == RR per MBMB
    numeric
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 5 / 5 points left]

    You must multiply the expression for the cost of each data type by the number of MBMB used. Then add these together and set them equal to the total cost.

    STEP: Set up the equation
    [−2 points ⇒ 3 / 5 points left]

    Mcebisi's total data costs are the sum of the amounts spent on in-bundle data and out-of-bundle data. To work out the amount spent on each type of data, we must multiply the number of MBMB used, with the cost of that type of data.

    Last week's in-bundle costs:

    cost=number of MB×cost per MB=44×y=44ycost=number of MB×cost per MB=44×y=44y

    Last week's out-of-bundle costs:

    cost=number of MB×cost per MB=6×(2y+1,4)=12y+8,4cost=number of MB×cost per MB=6×(2y+1,4)=12y+8,4

    We can now use this information to set up an equation.

    total coststotal costs =in-bundle costs=in-bundle costs +out-of-bundle costs+out-of-bundle costs
    103,6=44y+(12y+8,4)103,6=44y+(12y+8,4)

    STEP: Solve the equation
    [−2 points ⇒ 1 / 5 points left]
    103,6103,6103,6−8,495,295,2561,7=44y+(12y+8,4)=56y+8,4=56y+8,4−8,4=56y=56y56=y103,6=44y+(12y+8,4)103,6=56y+8,4103,6−8,4=56y+8,4−8,495,2=56y95,256=56y561,7=y

    Therefore in-bundle data costs R1,70R1,70 per MBMB.

    STEP: Calculate the cost of out-of-bundle data
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 5 points left]

    The question also asks for the cost of out-of-bundle data, per MBMB. We can use the value of yy, and the expression that we set up in Question 1.

    cost of out-of-bundle data (per MB)=2y+1,4=2(1,7)+1,4=3,4+1,4=4,8cost of out-of-bundle data (per MB)=2y+1,4=2(1,7)+1,4=3,4+1,4=4,8

    Therefore out-of-bundle data costs R4,80R4,80 per MBMB.

Set up and solve equations

Eric, Gift, and Isa are eating sweets.

  • Eric eats 33 less than Gift.
  • Isa eats two times more than Eric and Gift combined.
  • Altogether they ate 2727 sweets.

How many sweets did Gift eat?

TIP: Let the number of sweets eaten by Gift be gg.
Answer: Gift eats sweets.
numeric
HINT: <no title>
[−0 points ⇒ 6 / 6 points left]

Write the number of sweets that each person has in terms of gg. Add these terms together and set this equal to 2727, then solve the equation.

STEP: Write Eric's sweets in terms of gg
[−1 point ⇒ 5 / 6 points left]

Let the number of sweets eaten by Gift be gg.

We are told that Eric eats 33 less than Gift. This means that

Eric's sweets=Gift's sweets−3=g−3Eric's sweets=Gift's sweets−3=g−3
STEP: Write Isa's sweets in terms of gg
[−2 points ⇒ 3 / 6 points left]

    Therefore David has 1818 chocolates.

Set up and solve equations

Kate and Andrew attend school together. Kate has 44 more pencils than Andrew. Let the number of pencils that Andrew has be aa, and use this to answer the questions that follow.

TIP: The first step in translating a word problem into maths is to name an unknown quantity with a variable. In this question, that unknown is the number of pencils that Andrew has, and we have called that number aa.

  1. Write an expression for the number of pencils that Kate has, in terms of aa.

    Answer: Kate's pencils ==
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    To get the number of pencils that Kate has, you must add 44 to aa. Your answer will have an aa in it.

    STEP: Write Kate's number of pencils in terms of aa
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    We are told that Kate has 44 more pencils than Andrew has.

    To get the number of pencils that Kate has, you must add 44 to aa.

    Kate's pencils=a+4Kate's pencils=a+4
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Altogether, Kate and Andrew have 3030 pencils. How many pencils does Andrew have?

    TIP: It may be helpful to set up and solve an equation.
    Answer: a=a=
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    Add together the expressions for Kate and Andrew's items. Then set this equal to the total number of items.

    STEP: Create an equation
    [−1 point ⇒ 1 / 2 points left]

    We know that

    (Andrew's pencils)(Andrew's pencils) +(Kate's pencils)+(Kate's pencils) =30=30

    Now we can substitute in the expressions for Kate and Andrew in terms of aa:

    (a+4)(a+4) +(a)=30+(a)=30

    STEP: Solve the equation
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    We have an equation that we can solve, using techniques that we know already.

    a+4+a2a+42a+4−42a2a2a=30=30=30−4=26=262=13a+4+a=302a+4=302a+4−4=30−42a=262a2=262a=13

    Therefore Andrew has 1313 pencils.

A night at the movies

Last Friday, Chidiebere went to the movies with his friends. He bought chips and Jelly Tots to eat while he was there. The Jelly Tots cost R14R14 more than the chips, and the movie ticket cost twice what the Jelly Tots cost.

Let the cost of the chips be cc rand.

  1. Write an expression for the cost of the Jelly Tots, in terms of cc.

    Answer: Cost of the Jelly Tots == rand
    expression
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 1 / 1 points left]

    The chips costs cc, and the Jelly Tots costs R14R14 more than the chips. You must add R14R14 to cc. Your answer will have an cc in it.

    STEP: Write an expression for the cost of the Jelly Tots
    [−1 point ⇒ 0 / 1 points left]

    The chips cost cc, and the Jelly Tots costs R14R14 more than the chips. We must add 1414 to cc.

    cost of Jelly Tots=cost of chips+14=c+14cost of Jelly Tots=cost of chips+14=c+14
    Submit your answer as:

  2. Write a simplified expression for the cost of the movie ticket, in terms of cc.

    Answer: Cost of the movie ticket == rand
    one-of
    type(expression.strict)
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 2 / 2 points left]

    The movie ticket cost twice what the Jelly Tots cost. You must multiply the expression for the cost of Jelly Tots by 22.

    STEP: Write an expression for the cost of the movie
    [−2 points ⇒ 0 / 2 points left]

    The movie ticket cost twice what the Jelly Tots cost. We must multiply the expression for the cost of Jelly Tots by 22.

    cost of movie=2×(cost of Jelly Tots)=2×(c+14)=2c+28cost of movie=2×(cost of Jelly Tots)=2×(c+14)=2c+28
    Submit your answer as:

  3. If the total cost of Chidiebere's night at the movies was R102R102, use an equation to calculate the cost of the chips.

    Answer: Cost of chips == RR
    numeric
    HINT: <no title>
    [−0 points ⇒ 4 / 4 points left]

    You must add together the expressions for the costs of each item. Set this sum equal to the total cost, and solve the equation for cc.

    STEP: Set up the equation
    [−1 point ⇒ 3 / 4 points left]

    We were told that the total cost of the outing was R102R102. This means that if we add together the costs of the chips, the Jelly Tots, and the movie, it will come to R102R102.

    chips+Jelly Tots+moviec+(c+14)+(2c+28)=102=102chips+Jelly Tots+movie=102c+(c+14)+(2c+28)=102
    STEP: Solve the equation
    [−3 points ⇒ 0 / 4 points left]

    c+(c+14)+(2c+28)4c+424c+42−424c4c4c=102=102=102−42=60=604=15c+(c+14)+(2c+28)=1024c+42=1024c+42−42=102−424c=604c4=604c=15

    Therefore the chips cost R15R15.
